text: I don’t have specific books in mind, but for a general reading curriculum, I might suggest one book on Dreyfus, one on the interwar/Vichy right (Brown’s “The Embrace of Unreason” is a good popular history), and one on the National Front.
author: dhmontgomery

text: For background, there’s always René Rémond’s “The Right Wing in France: From 1815 to de Gaulle.” But its pre-1880s stuff might be too distant for someone focused on modern race-based concerns.
author: dhmontgomery

text:
If your goal is to maximize ridership, yes. That’s not the only possible goal you can set. “Improve the system for those who need it most” is an equally valid normative conclusion from this mental model.

I’m saying criticism should go toward those moral judgments, not the model.
author: dhmontgomery

text: Yes. Obviously everyone wants all of that. But when resources are constrained some aspects of the system get prioritized over others.
author: dhmontgomery

text: And choice riders want a comprehensive system. It’s not that some people don’t want certain aspects, it’s that different aspects of the system matter more to different people.
author: dhmontgomery

text: From a policy perspective, too, expanding transit has different impacts depending on whether the people you’re expanding transit to. Someone without a car getting transit expands their capacity & mobility. Someone with a car getting transit takes cars off the road.
author: dhmontgomery

text: All users want the transit system to be as good as possible, of course. But for someone with no other way to get around, comprehensiveness is a huge priority. Someone who COULD drive if they want to is generally speaking going to prioritize speed & efficiency more.
author: dhmontgomery

text: What don’t you like about that term? I’ve always found “riders by choice” and “riders by necessity" a useful way to conceive of the two broad types of transit users, who have different needs and demands from a hypothetical system.
author: dhmontgomery

text: As long as it’s after your ggplot() call, order doesn’t really matter for that kind of stuff. It usually only matters if you’re drawing multiple geoms and want to control which goes on top.

text: Another neat trick, especially if your percentage data is in decimal form, is + scales::scale_x_continuous(labels = percent). Auto-formats axes into percents. (labels = percent_format(accuracy = 1) might be more to your liking, depending on your rounding preferences.)

text: François Guizot, the leader of the Parti de la Résistance during the later years of the July Monarchy, used patronage, state pressure and the restricted franchise to ensure majorities for his unpopular government, which worked until the 1848 Revolution sent him packing.
author: dhmontgomery

text: The Parti du Mouvement was generally the opposition party in a system marked by limited suffrage (which they wanted to expand, somewhat) and by a constitutional monarch of center-right leanings. They were also handicapped by their opponents’ political chicanery.
author: dhmontgomery

text: In particular, the two parties split over their view of the past, and specifically the Revolution of 1830, which both had supported. The Resistance (the center-right, then), thought the July Revolution a completed project; the Mouvement thought it an ongoing process.
author: dhmontgomery

text: France in the 1830s had a sort of unofficial, quasi-organized two-party system: the “Parti du Mouvement” and “Parti de la Résistance,” reflecting respectively reformism and conservatism or defense of “order” — attitudes rather than specific policy platforms.
author: dhmontgomery

text: (That should be “KAD-ree”, not “NAD-ree,” obviously.)
author: dhmontgomery

text: (Basically the same issue as “forte”.)
author: dhmontgomery

text: “If a word has already been fully anglicized, there is little purpose in returning halfway… To say, as the British do, KAH-dur… strikes me as more sensible than saying KAH-dray, which is neither French nor English… KAD-ree may not sound pretty, but it is definitely English."
author: dhmontgomery

text: “To my ear, KAH-dray sounds affected. It is what I call a de-anglicized pronunciation, an attempt to return to what speakers imagine is the original, or foreign, pronunciation of the word. In this case, KAH-dray makes the word sound as if it came from Italian or Spanish…"
author: dhmontgomery

text: “In the first half of the century dictionaries gave the pronunciation KAH-dur, after the French… Then they began recording another pronunciation, NAD-ree, common among the military… another variant, KAH-dray, which has also been recorded since the 1960s, has overtaken KAD-ree."
author: dhmontgomery

text: I’ve always heard it like “cadré”. But my “The Big Book of Beastly Mispronunciations” has a short essay on it, and recommends the “KAD-ree” pronunciation.
author: dhmontgomery

text: I’m not saying get rid of the UI options, just create an option for a new view I could link to if I wanted to share a spreadsheet with the non-technical public while still letting the technical audience go under the hood.
author: dhmontgomery

text: Mostly, yes. (I can think of some uses for doing it with a private repo, like sharing it with a non-coder boss or something, but the primary use case I’m envisioning is public-facing.)
author: dhmontgomery

text: Also maybe a way to display a document like a CSV in pretty form, but w/ the usual Github chrome minimized so as to not scare away non-technical users with options they don’t need & terms they don’t understand like “fork” or “pull request", keeping the focus on the one document.
author: dhmontgomery

text: For using Github to share data with non-technical people, some more complicated things that could help: rudimentary search functions for CSVs, and maybe some ability — I’m not sure how! — to provide or link to extra context/labels/annotations from the CSV’s page on Github.
author: dhmontgomery

text: That seems like it would be relatively simple to implement and even A/B test (though everything has complications, of course). People tossed out some more elaborate ideas in the thread earlier.
author: dhmontgomery

text: (Being able to do this for sub-repository folders would be nice too. Sometimes people host multiple distinct elements inside a single repository and you just want part of it.)
author: dhmontgomery

text: My idea: add a “download file” button when you’re on a file's page (in addition to the existing option to download a whole repository). Non-technies sometimes just want that CSV you’re hosting, and “right-click Raw and choose Save As” is not intuitive for many.

text: 10/10 In conclusion, the rest of my evening is spent trying to decide which recording of what may be my new favorite 18th Century choral work. (Handel’s “Messiah” and Bach’s “Mass in B Minor” are the other contenders. I think I need to give Handel a deeper dive…)
author: dhmontgomery

text: 9/ In the video you can see the singers start to smile in anticipation as this break nears. @JCROMMEREIM noted that the singers & “sometimes even the conductor have had to restrain themselves from playing air guitar and doing heavy metal head-banging to along to the beat."
author: dhmontgomery

text: 8/ Everything suddenly stops mid-movement, and then starting with the baritones, the choir begins a ferocious staccato chanting over the words, “conquasabit capita” — literally “He will crush the heads,” from Psalm 110. This part happens around 21:30.
author: dhmontgomery

text: 7/ But the most stunning moment in the piece is in the middle, in the “Judicabit” movement. The first 2.5 minutes or so are along the lines of what you’ve come to expect by now. But then Handel throws a complete curve ball.
author: dhmontgomery

text: 6/ And the concluding movement is a stunning climax, a fugue of sorts called a “cantus firmus”, in which part of the ensemble sings a tune in long notes while the rest “swirls around it with florid counterpoint,” melody passing from section to section: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dS65-ZvUSSM …
author: dhmontgomery

text: 5/ The penultimate “De torrente" movement is also beautiful, a soprano duet whose languid pace and flowing accompaniment makes it seem as if “time has almost stopped,” as @JCROMMEREIM wrote in his program notes: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dS65-ZvUSSM …
author: dhmontgomery

text: 4/ I also love the recapitulation of the theme by the baritones at 1:30, after a lovely melodic solo in between.
author: dhmontgomery

text: 3/ This is a recording by John Eliot Gardner and the Monteverdi Choir. Notice how it grabs you right away, both with the pulsing instrumental intro and then when the chorus emphatically enters at 0:42:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dS65-ZvUSSM …
author: dhmontgomery

text: 2/ The version I saw was by @Lyra_Baroque and the @GrinnellCollege Singers. Sadly they don’t have a “Dixit Dominus" recording I can link to, but they should make one! A tour-de-force, and a piece I’d never heard of as a modest classical music fan.
author: dhmontgomery

text: Just got back from a baroque concert. Bach’s "Mass in A Major" was fine. But the performance of Handel’s “Dixit Dominus” was an absolute revelation. Completely electric. There were stunned murmurs between movements — for a piece composed in 1707!  I’m still buzzing. 1/
author: dhmontgomery

text: HW Brands’ recent history notes that Harrison shrugged off suggestions that he should change into warm, dry clothes, observing he had endured worse in his days as a soldier. Except Harrison no longer had a young man’s constitution.

text: Harrison had been feeling sick in the weeks before his inauguration. But that week he felt better, which inspired him to soldier through a long inaugural speech in miserable conditions. He then caught sick and died.

text: I don’t really disagree on that point. Everything has tradeoffs but the benefits of a more aggressive site moderation would seem to outweigh the costs.
author: dhmontgomery

text: I was responding to your comment earlier: “Really, the website should probably just be launched into the sun; AskHistorians could be collateral damage."
author: dhmontgomery

text: So the structural problem with Reddit is… an insufficiently aggressive banhammer? I don’t disagree that’d be an improvement, I’m just not seeing how that’s such a fundamental flaw it’s calls for a “burn it all down” response.
author: dhmontgomery

text: At a certain point, it’s not that a community is bad, it’s that a certain subset of people are bad. And if your community is at any scale at all — if you’re not gated and requiring permission to be a member — I’m not sure if that’s something that can be suppressed.
author: dhmontgomery

text: Right, but… those are people seeking others out harass them in private. It’s awful (and something that as a straight white male writing about European history I’ve never had to experience) but I’m not sure how much of that is down to community design.
author: dhmontgomery

text: The late innings of #SpringTraining games are such bizarre fun.
author: dhmontgomery

text: The fact that Reddit has some real cesspools too doesn’t detract from my enjoyment of its non-cesspool corners, because Reddit lets you cultivate your experience to (more or less) avoid places that don’t bring you joy.
author: dhmontgomery

text: Places like r/dataisbeautiful, r/mapporn, some RPG-focused subs, even r/baseball are pretty free of the nastiest aspects of the internet with modest moderation. They could certainly be cleaner with more aggressive modding, but they’re far from a wasteland.
author: dhmontgomery

text: I dunno. Obvious @askhistorians is the best place on @Reddit, but as long as you just subscribe to subreddits you like and never, ever visit r/all, it can be a great site even outside its most intensely moderated corners.
author: dhmontgomery
